content.text: Two point masses are separated by a distance \(x\) in a vacuum
State an expression for the force \(F\) between the two masses \(M\) and \(m\)
State the name of any other symbol used
The rod hangs from a vertical thread and is horizontal
The distance from the centre of sphere S to the thread is 8.0 cm
A large sphere L is placed near to sphere S, as shown in Fig. 1.2
There is a force of attraction between spheres S and L, causing sphere S to move through a distance of \(1.2 \text{mm}\)
The line joining the centres of S and L is normal to the rod
Show that the angle \(\theta\) through which the rod rotates is \(1.5 \times 10^{-2} \text{rad}\)
The rotation of the rod causes the thread to twist
The torque \(T\) (in Nm) required to twist the thread through an angle \(\beta\) (in rad) is given by
Calculate the torque in the thread when sphere L is positioned as shown in Fig. 1.2
torque =   .........  Nm
A small sphere S is attached to one end of a rod, as shown in Fig. 1.1
view from side
By equating the torque in (b)(ii) to the moment about the thread produced by gravitational attraction between the spheres, calculate a value for the gravitational constant
gravitational constant =   .........  Nm²kg⁻²
Suggest why the total force between the spheres may not be equal to the force calculated using Newton's law of gravitation
The distance between the centres of spheres S and L is \(6.0 \text{cm}\)
The mass of sphere S is \(7.5 \text{g}\) and the mass of sphere L is \(1.3 \text{kg}\)
State, for a system, what is meant by:
State what is represented by a negative value of \(\Delta U\)
The first law of thermodynamics may be expressed in the form
State and explain the total change in internal energy of the gas for one complete cycle ABCA
Calculate the external work done on the gas during the expansion from point C to point A
work done =   .........  J
Complete Fig. 2.2 for the changes from:
1. point A to point B
2. point B to point C
3. point C to point A
An ideal gas, sealed in a container, undergoes the cycle of changes shown in Fig. 2.1
At point A, the gas has volume \(2.4 \times 10^{-3} \text{m}^3\), pressure \(1.6 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\) and temperature \(300 \text{K}\)

The gas is compressed suddenly so that no thermal energy enters or leaves the gas during the compression. The amount of work done is \(480 \text{J}\) so that, at point B, the gas has volume \(8.7 \times 10^{-4} \text{m}^3\), pressure \(6.6 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\) and temperature \(450 \text{K}\)
The gas is now cooled at constant volume so that, between points B and C, 1100 J of thermal energy is transferred. At point C, the gas has pressure \(1.6 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\) and temperature 110K
Finally, the gas is returned to point A
one time at which the mass is moving with maximum speed
one time at which the spring has maximum elastic potential energy
State:
the angular frequency \(\omega\)
the maximum speed
maximum speed =   .........  \(\text{ms}^{-1}\)
the magnitude of the maximum acceleration
maximum acceleration =   .........  \(\text{ms}^{-2}\)
Use data from Fig. 3.2 to determine, for the motion of the mass:
The mass M is now suspended from two springs, each identical to that in Fig. 3.1, as shown in Fig. 3.3
Suggest and explain the change, if any, in the period of oscillation of the mass. A numerical answer is not required
A spring is hung vertically from a fixed point. A mass M is hung from the other end of the spring, as illustrated in Fig. 3.1
The mass is displaced downwards and then released. The subsequent motion of the mass is simple harmonic
The variation with time \(t\) of the length \(L\) of the spring is shown in Fig. 3.2
State what is meant by the specific acoustic impedance of a medium
A parallel beam of ultrasound of intensity \(I_0\) is incident on the boundary between two media A and B, as illustrated in Fig. 4.1
The two media A and B have specific acoustic impedances \(Z_{\mathrm{A}}\) and \(Z_{\mathrm{B}}\) respectively
The intensity of the beam transmitted through the boundary is \(I_{\mathrm{T}}\)
State how the ratio
depends on the relative magnitudes of \(Z_{\mathrm{A}}\) and \(Z_{\mathrm{B}}\)
The linear absorption (attenuation) coefficient \(\mu\) of medium B is \(23 \text{m}^{-1}\)
Calculate the thickness of medium B required to reduce the intensity of the ultrasound beam to \(34\%\) of its initial intensity in medium B
thickness =   .........  m
attenuation
noise
For a signal transmitted along an optic fibre, state what is meant by:
Calculate the attenuation per unit length, in \(\mathrm{dB} \mathrm{km}^{- 1}\), in the transmission line
attenuation per unit length =   .........  dB km\({}^{-1}\)
The gain of the amplifier is 115 dB
Calculate the power of the signal at the output of the amplifier
The initial section of the transmission line for a signal from a telephone exchange is illustrated in Fig. 5.1
At the exchange, the input signal to the transmission line has a power of \(2.5 \times 10^{-3} \text{W}\)
After the signal has travelled a distance of \(52\mathrm{km}\) along the transmission line, the power of the signal is \(7.8\times 10^{-16}\mathrm{W}.\) The signal is then amplified
State what is meant by _electric potential_ at a point
Two parallel metal plates A and B are held a distance \(d\) apart in a vacuum, as illustrated in Fig. 6.1
Plate A is earthed and plate B is at a potential of \(+V_0\)
Point P is situated in the centre region between the plates at a distance \(x\) from plate B
The potential at point P is \(V.\)
On Fig. 6.2, show the variation with \(x\) of the potential \(V\) for values of \(x\) from \(x = 0\) to \(x = d.\)
Two isolated solid metal spheres M and N, each of radius \(R\), are situated in a vacuum. Their centres are a distance \(D\) apart, as illustrated in Fig. 6.3
Each sphere has charge \(+Q\)
Point P lies on the line joining the centres of the two spheres, and is a distance \(y\) from the centre of sphere M
On Fig. 6.4, show the variation with distance \(y\) of the electric potential at point P, for values of \(y\) from \(y = 0\) to \(y = D\)
Fig. 6.4

The initial direction of the electron is at an angle of \(30^{\circ}\) to the direction of the magnetic field
